title: Biden says default would risk market tanking, as he meets CEOs of J.P. Morgan, Intel, Nasdaq
text:
Biden met with a group that included J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. JPM CEO Jamie Dimon, Intel INTC CEO Pat Gelsinger and Adena Friedman, president and CEO of Nasdaq NDAQ. Other participants included Jo Ann Jenkins, the CEO of AARP. Executives joined either in-person or virtually.

“We need to act,” Biden said, as leaders including Dimon echoed what the president said was an urgent need. “We should never even get this close,” the bank chief said.

Republicans say they won't help Democrats raise the borrowing limit, arguing Biden's party should do it on their own.

Congress has just days to act before the Oct. 18 deadline when the Treasury Department has warned it will run short of funds to pay the nation's already accrued debt load. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen attended the meeting and reiterated that date.

In a blog post on Wednesday, members of the White House Council of Economic Advisers said “if Congress fails to act, it could take decades for the United States to fully recover.”

Senate Democrats on Wednesday are scheduled to try for a third time to suspend the borrowing limit, while Republicans are expected to block the move.

Meanwhile, reports were emerging that Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell will offer to Majority Leader Chuck Schumer a proposal to end the standoff over the borrowing limit.

The proposal is “going to give us a way out of the woods,” Republican Sen. Lisa Murkowski of Alaska told reporters on Wednesday.

The Associated Press contributed to this story.
